{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is presenting with syncope and increasing shortness of breath while exercising, which suggests a cardiac etiology. The vital signs are within normal limits. Palpation of the carotid artery shows 2 closely spaced pulses during systole. These findings are most consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The murmur is accentuated by maneuvers that decrease left ventricular volume, such as forceful expiration against a closed airway. The 2 closely spaced pulses during systole are known as bisferiens pulses and are characteristic of HCM. Aortic stenosis can also cause a systolic ejection murmur, but it is typically heard best at the right upper sternal border and does not cause bisferiens pulses.
